utterances.sentences: Yes. These sanctions are pretty biting, as the president said, Geraldo. Commercial aircraft, precious metals, carpet exports, industrial software, cars and sovereign debt. utterances.sentences: There is no doubt but that these sanctions are biting, and they will accomplish, I think, the goal, which is to get Iran to negotiate on the nuclear deal. And I think the president should take up the whole idea of meeting with Rouhani. I like when he meets these people face-to-face. I believe he has the unique and unprecedented, extraordinary ability in the face-to-face negotiations to do something. However, I think that our entire policy vis-a-vis Iran is bankrupt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I think that we have totally picked the wrong enemy in the Middle East. In my experience, in decades of war reporting, the nuisance, the evildoer is Saudi Arabia. The Iranians, I believe we could do business with them. They're the sheikhs of Rodeo Drive in Southern California.

utterances.speaker: CANDACE OWENS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: There could be more than one problem.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: They're the Persians. I think that we really have gone --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, it's the regime in Iran we have the problem with.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: We've been -- we've been bought and purchased by the Saudis.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: That's exactly what I was going to say.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not the people.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The Saudis have bought and purchased American foreign policy.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Exactly what I was going to say, Jesse. This is an oppressive regime. I don't understand why America would be helping to fund or give cash to an oppressive regime. utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The way the Saudis did?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I think --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Geraldo. It hurts to say this, but he does have a point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I mean, the Saudis have been around. We talk about Iranian terror, we also say they're the largest state.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: In the 20th Century, maybe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But that's right. It's very hard to say, "Well, which ones ones?" That have -- that in America. But we know which ones in America were Saudis.

utterances.speaker: OWENS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: And he's got to tackle all of it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: It's hard to be the president.

utterances.sentences: You also have the situation that you have now and that has changed. Don't you think, Geraldo, that the Saudis are trying to figure out a way?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. They're trying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The Iranians are not.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA

No one is holding them to task. They are blockading other peaceful Arab countries. I mean, it is outrageous to me that we don't see our own self-interest because of Saudi money, Saudi oil.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- with the Saudis because of oil, and we can deal with them next after we deal with the Iranians, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: A Democratic candidate dreams about America with open borders ahead.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: I don't know what this is. RIVERA (singing): "Yo Quiero Dinero Tambien."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: "I want money, too.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Very good, Dana. Very good. The battle over what to do about America's broken immigration system rages on, as you know. A Democratic candidate for governor in the border state of Arizona raising eyebrows with his vision of the future.

utterances.speaker: DAVID GARCIA (D), ARIZONA GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: I want to just take a second and imagine. Let's just imagine. Just imagine no wall. No wall in southern Arizona.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Mr. Garcia's dream of no wall is Donald Trump's nightmare, as you know. The president refusing to back away from his campaign promise to build the wall. Candace, you're filled with fury. Do you think the president should shut the government down, if necessary, to get funding for the border wall? Is it worth it to -- life or death, do you know what I mean?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Look, I just want to take a second and imagine, if everyone could just imagine a world with no borders. You would see drugs flying in. Children in Arizona specifically, that is the state that has the highest child sex trafficking over that border. So that is the world that he is imagining right now, where there are no rules and no regulation, and that's OK. I always ask the question: What bothers you more? The idea of a child being temporarily separated from their parents or a child that is a part of a sex trafficking ring? Because that is what this question comes down to.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I appreciate the emotional appeal of this point.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: He needs to take a hard line on this issue. I believe -- I support him. I agree that, if the government has to shut down to get it done, let the government shut down.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Jesse, is it worth that much?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: If he shuts it --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And this is weeks before the midterms.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: If he shuts it down, he has to get the funding. Because if he shuts it down and doesn't get the funding, that's going to be an absolute catastrophe for not only his approval rating with his base but also the people running for reelection. So it needs 60 votes in the Senate as is. I don't see it happening that way. I'm a little nervous about the wall. They're just going to have to do it brick by brick. I wish we didn't have to build a wall. Mexico wouldn't have to pay for it then, because it's very expensive. But unfortunately, you need the wall to stop illegal immigration. And all these Democrats keep telling me when they're in this chair, "Oh, the Democratic Party doesn't believe in open borders." OK, well, this guy does. Hillary Clinton, WikiLeaks, she said she didn't believe in borders. You had the No. 2 at the DNC, Keith Ellison, wear a T-shirt that says, "I Don't Believe in Borders." Every time someone -- abolish ICE. They don't want to fund the wall. They don't want borders, because they want the votes, and that's part of their party platform. It's just not a winning strategy.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Jim Jordan, you know him, Dana. Candidate for speaker the next time around, in Ryan's absence. He says, "It's worth the fight. He says, "Shut it down if we have to. The wall is what you ran on. It's been 18 months, no progress. I say" -- Jordan says, also an Ohio congressman, he says shut it down. What say you, having been close to the heart of power?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: My first day on the job as the press secretary on Capitol Hill was the first day of the first government shutdown in 1995. And I didn't know if I should go to work or not, because I wasn't sure if I was essential. I just think government by shutdown is really not a good way to do business. But also because of the partisanship, it's hard to get anything done. The best thing that the Republicans could do is try to stem their losses that they could face in the House, try to maybe win some. As the president said, a red wave. That's how you prevent government shutdown, is if you have more of your people. Shutting down the government and then not getting the money and then having to say, "Well, actually we are getting the wall, because we are doing these improvements," which are actually already happening. That would probably be a better strategic way to do it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I agree. But Greg, you've got firebrands on both sides. There's no way, if the Republicans are threatening a shutdown, if the president is threatening a shutdown, there's no way the Democrats will yield.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: They will prolong the agony to unsettle the electorate on the eve of the midterms and could indeed -- you know, are you willing to stake the future of the party on this one issue?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I would normally say no, but I have been wrong so many times in the last couple of years, especially about Trump's policies. And -- and I'm beginning to see evidence that Trump's immigration policies are beneficial to the lower rungs of the employment ladder. And it's something he should -- I think he has been talking about it, but I don't know if he's linked it to the immigration policies. So as we see illegal immigration decline, there's been an increase in native-born employment, a small increase, like 1 percent, I believe. But that's not -- that doesn't mean whites. That means blacks and Hispanics who are legal citizens here who are actually getting jobs. So that may be why his popularity is rising among blacks and Hispanics. It's something like 29 percent among blacks. So they have to show that maybe Trump's policies are having a definite effect on employment. I -- this has been a debate forever.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Of course. Having a debate. Illegal immigration directly hurts the black community. That's who it affects, No. 1.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's bogus. Totally bogus.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I totally --

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: There are actually --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The black community is not going to go to the --

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: The black labor force, the highest --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- poultry processing plants, the meat-packing plants.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: No, you're absolutely incorrect. OK?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Black unemployment is below 5 percent. Where are you going to find these black people?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: No, OK, yes, thanks to Trump's policies.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Where you going to find black people? Where you going to find Latinos?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Sitting right next to you.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: But you have a job. And you're a citizen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She's gutting chicken right now.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: My advice to the president is to secretly negotiate with Schumer. You get the wall. He gets the DREAMers. Give a green light to the DREAMers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They had that.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: He said it. He's offered the DREAMers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They had 25 billion for the wall, and they had DREAMers. And it got yanked off the table.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I want the 2013 compromise legislation passed --

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: They don't want compromise.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- by the United States Senate. That's what I want. They don't want compromise, Candace. You're right.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: We've got to stop pretending they want to compromise. They put that on the table. He put the DACA on the table. They didn't want that. All they want to do is obstruct. And he's going to have to take a hard line to accomplish anything in the administration.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: So you say fight to the finish?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: And I take great exception. Because it's factual. The unemployment, illegal immigration directly affects the black labor force first and foremost.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I absolutely disagree. I've written two books on the subject. I absolutely -- I think that you are one of the most vivid and appealing and intelligent new commentators --

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Let's end it there.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- on the team -- on the team today, but you are wrong about that.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not wrong.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's what the breaks are for.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: -- after this, guys.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: One critic wants to pull the plug on one of America's reality TV guilty pleasures. Find out what and why next.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: One TV critic wants to do away with rose ceremonies and fantasy suites on TV. She says it's time to retire reality TV dating shows like "The Bachelorette" for good. The writer argues that, in the "#MeToo" era, throwing strangers together to find love and happiness on screen is anything but rosy. Is this too much? Why can't Americans just enjoy trashy TV? I will ask you that question, Greg. Why can't Americans just enjoy trashy TV?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I feel very strongly about this. I don't even believe it's trashy. What I see -- I see it as a purely biological attraction. That people are interested in stories. They're interested in romance. And romance can be sloppy. That's part of it. Dating shows also reveal the enemy of the hard left: biology. Men and women are different down to their very cells, and you see this in these shows. You can't change these types of shows with political action. And what drives me crazy as we are now dealing with a modern version of Big Brother. We are a nation of narcs. We see people having fun, right, and we want to eliminate people having fun. It's an elimination of entertainment and fun. We're going after costumes. We're going after dating shows.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Plastic straws.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Plastic straws. We're going after sports. Every single person has to have fun and agree on it, or no one can have fun. That's where we're headed. We're -- we are a nation of narcs and fun police. And they're all miserable people. You come -- the writer has to be miserable to come out against this.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: No chance that writer voted for Donald Trump. Dana, question for you. A lot, to me, seems to be going under this umbrella of "#MeToo."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Can you perhaps connect the dots here?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And I think that everything is -- they're trying to --

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: "The Bachelorette" and "#MeToo"?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, everything is under -- they're trying to put it in. Yes, everything is being put in under that. Here's -- for me, I don't like this program, "The Bachelorette."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How dare you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But guess what?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Neither do I.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't watch it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The whole audience is women.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's my choice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK, but can I interrupt?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: That's too reasonable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's supposed to be a violation of "#MeToo." The entire audience is women and me. It's, like, 99 percent women --

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: You, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- and me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I've been through Brad, Juan Pablo --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- JoJo, Andy. I've seen them all. Except this season I stopped watching. I love the show. I think it's romantic.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Romantic?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And I have teared up on a few of these episodes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You have. I've seen it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Poor boy. Poor Jess.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's incredibly interesting. And I think what they're trying to do, they want to eliminate men courting women in America because of the "#MeToo" movement. And that's not -- no one crosses the line on the show.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Didn't they have some kind of seedy thing happen, where it was supposed to be --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: On a reality show, Geraldo? You don't say.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Somebody said it wasn't -- it was nonconsensual?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Was it "Bachelors in Paradise"?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, that's sad, and that should be handled.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was "Bachelors in Paradise."

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Then it ended up being resolved, and they both said that it was consensual and that the producers made it something that it wasn't. So let's clarify that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They were trying to get some controversy so we would talk about it on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I have considerable reality experience. I did the "Celebrity Apprentice." There was no sex in that. But "Dancing with the Stars" --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: With you anyway.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I did "Dancing with the Stars." I was already 73 years old when I did it. I was lame, I was awful. And they had asked me for 20 years or ten years or however long the show's been around to do "Dancing with the Stars." And my kids and my wife always said, "Don't do it. Don't do it. Everybody has affairs with the dancers." All of the celebrities have affairs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I didn't know that.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: So I didn't do it until I was passed a fair age.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That happened a lot on Lawrence Welk, I hear.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Interesting. The London -- the London School of Economics had a study. I don't know why they were doing a study. Saying that "The Kardashians" -- watching "The Kardashians" makes people not like poor people. So this is also another concern --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: -- is that we are starting not o like being poor in this country.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I thought you were going to say it was like taking away their I.Q.'s.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Why are they studying this at the London School of Economics?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're trying to -- they're trying to link it to status inequality when you see people doing well. But it's actually aspirational.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I don't buy that at all. Aspirational.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: It's good. They don't want to be poor. What's wrong with that? What is wrong with capitalism?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: They're saying 15 years in television. "The Kardashians." No such thing as an accident in TV.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: One time I watched, like, five hours of "Bridezillas."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Bridezillas."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because it was raining and we were someplace. And it -- that was horrible. That was really bad.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You should see "The Jersey Shore." It was horrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I like "Bar Rescue." Do you guys watch "Bar Rescue"?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's time for "One More Thing," Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Here we go. "Jesse's Eyebrow News."

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Jesse's Eyebrow News."

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Oh, God.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We have it. Look at it, look at it! You missed it, Gutfeld! They went up and down. All right. So Rihanna has some new eyebrows she's rocking. They're thin. All right? See that right there on the cover? So a Latina writer from "Marie Claire" wrote that this is cultural appropriation.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And it was problematic, because --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's the word!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- they were too thin for Rihanna. Rihanna responded with this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So Rihanna, let's see the -- this email from Rihanna goes, "I'm feeling thin eyebrows."

utterances.speaker: RIHANNA, MUSICIAN
utterances.sentences: Thin eyebrows are such a beautiful, very ladylike. But it's still punk.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. These eyebrows are not thin, and that is your eyebrow news of the day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Jesse. I'm glad you navigated that carefully -- Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Thousands of fans and more than 4,000 dog surfers showed up to the Third Annual World Dog Surfing Championships in Pacifica, California, over the weekend.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Terrible.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The owners and their four-legged friends rode the waves just outside of San Francisco to see who has the best moves. The judges were human and scored each surfer based on their ability to stand, ride, and move in the wave style. That's also a huge plus. The championship is more than just fun and games. Each year a portion of the proceeds of the event go to dog surfing. And, of course, it's California, environmental charities. Let me add "One More Thing." Do you know that the water off the coast of San Diego is 73 degrees right now?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow, that's fantastic.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You could take a bath in there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Antifa won't. All right. It's time for --

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Cable News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Cable News"! If you were watching CNN last night, boy, did Michael Avenatti and Rudy Giuliani go after it! Check out this tape.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Just wait. Ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh! Did they go away?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We're at the break.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, no. And then he said something else. And then. They're back at it. This went on for three hours! Good job, CNN. All right, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: That was excellent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: My wife is with me. We're celebrating our anniversary here in New York. When we got together, no one gave us any chance of success at all. I was 60 years old. Erica was 28 years old. The consensus were that we would last 15 weeks. We lasted 15 years. Our 15th anniversary is Saturday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: My beautiful wife Erica. We also celebrate our daughter, Sol Ileana. Her 13th birthday is a bar mitzvah year. It was August the second. She's a doll, the joy of our life. We love her. And I'm so happy that things have turned out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And so many were wrong, and I was right.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: All right, guys. I want you to feel good going into hump day. So one song, over 4.5 million views later. A family from Anchorage, Alaska, has become an Internet sensation with their a cappella version of the hit single by Bebe Rexha and Florida Georgia Line, "Meant to Be." Let's roll the clip.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: Look at the girl in the back dancing. This makes me just so happy, because Jesus is becoming something cool to celebrate again, culturally relevant. This family is singing about Jesus. They have an entire Instagram page, a YouTube page, of them just celebrating the good Lord, which is a beautiful message and a great way to end --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But the Saudis! The Saudis are our enemy, Candace! Don't you know?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.sentences: We all looked at it, America. We all looked at it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Geraldo is the one throwing punches this time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Set your DVRs, whatever that means. She is a news cannon, and her name is Shannon. Hi, Shannon.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: Hi, Greg. We're ready to explode with a bunch of breaking news.
